Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Mechanical Activation of Amorphous Shape Memory Polymers

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) project is to elucidate the mechanisms controlling the performance of shape memory polymers during mechanical activation. Amorphous shape memory polymers can be programmed to store a temporary shape by applying deformation and cooling below the glass transition temperature. The material recovers the permanent shape when reheated above the transition temperature. The polymer structure can be tailored to meet a broad range of mechanical and biological requirements. This makes them attractive for applications in the biomedical device industry; yet they have not gained wider acceptance because of their slow recovery times. In mechanical activation, mechanical work is applied in addition to temperature to accelerate shape recovery. The research will investigate the importance of two mechanisms, molecular orientation and structural relaxation, on the force requirements for mechanical activation. The effect of shape memory programming conditions and physical aging on mechanical behavior will be measured. Constitutive models will be developed to investigate the effect of material properties and temperature and loading conditions on mechanical activation.

The research will enable the development of more precise programming and more efficient manufacturing strategies for mechanically activated devices. The developed models will help to characterize the safety and performance of these devices throughout their intended shelf life, which can lead to a wider acceptance in the biomedical device industry. Student researchers will gain industry experience through summer internships at a leading company for shape memory polymer medical devices. The research will be integrated into courses to include the mechanics of smart polymers.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The shape memory effect in polymers allows the material to be programmed by deformation and temperature to store a temporary shape and recover a permanent shape in response to a variety of external stimuli like temperature and solvent absorption.  It was also found that the programmed material was significantly softer than the unprogrammed material such that mechanical loading can be applied to return the material to its original shape.  The  goal of the project was to investigate the influence of the temperature and deformation conditions of shape  programming  on the shape recovery behavior and  to identify the mechanism that enables mechanically driven recovery.   To achieve these objectives we developed physics based models for the nonequiibrium behavior of amorphous polymers through the glass transition. We also conducted experiments to obtain the model parameters and to characterize the shape recovery behavior driven by temperature, solvent absorption and mechanical loading. We found that the tremendous change in the molecular mobility (ability for the polymer moleculars to rearrange its position) caused by the glass transition, annealing, and plastic deformation is the underlying mechanism of these different recovery behavior.  Mechanical activation is the result of mechanical rejuvenation, where plastic strain produces a more disordered polymer structure resulting in a lower yield strength.  Solvent-driven shape memory behavior is entirely analogous to temperature-driven shape memory behavior.  The absorption of solvent depresses the glass transition temperature, which causes a material to soften and undergo the glass transition.  Solvent-driven shape memory also exhibits a temperature-memory effect as well as multi-stage recovery.  The degree of shape recovery depends on the degree that the solvent molecules can increase the molecular mobility of the chains and can be related to the degree of swelling of the polymer in solvent. These findings and tools developed by this project will enable the more efficient design of shape memory polymers and devices for a variety of industry including aerospace, biomedical and manufacture.  

 


Last Modified: 10/21/2016
Modified by: Thao (Vicky) D Nguyen
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The shape memory effect in polymers allows the material to be programmed by deformation and temperature to store a temporary shape and recover a permanent shape in response to a variety of external stimuli like temperature and solvent absorption. It was also found that the programmed material was significantly softer than the unprogrammed material such that mechanical loading can be applied to return the material to its original shape. The goal of the project was to investigate the influence of the temperature and deformation conditions of shape programming on the shape recovery behavior and to identify the mechanism that enables mechanically driven recovery. To achieve these objectives we developed physics based models for the nonequiibrium behavior of amorphous polymers through the glass transition. We also conducted experiments to obtain the model parameters and to characterize the shape recovery behavior driven by temperature, solvent absorption and mechanical loading. We found that the tremendous change in the molecular mobility (ability for the polymer moleculars to rearrange its position) caused by the glass transition, annealing, and plastic deformation is the underlying mechanism of these different recovery behavior. Mechanical activation is the result of mechanical rejuvenation, where plastic strain produces a more disordered polymer structure resulting in a lower yield strength. Solvent-driven shape memory behavior is entirely analogous to temperature-driven shape memory behavior. The absorption of solvent depresses the glass transition temperature, which causes a material to soften and undergo the glass transition. Solvent-driven shape memory also exhibits a temperature-memory effect as well as multi-stage recovery. The degree of shape recovery depends on the degree that the solvent molecules can increase the molecular mobility of the chains and can be related to the degree of swelling of the polymer in solvent. These findings and tools developed by this project will enable the more efficient design of shape memory polymers and devices for a variety of industry including aerospace, biomedical and manufacture.
